properties.media:imagetext:
Hongkong Jan. 13, 1938
Dearest Debs;
I may have felt lower than now at some time or other but
can't remember when.
In the first place I have been counting on com-
ing back to Manila ever since arriving here and regret now that I didn't
come back on the ship which brought me over here.
I have been on the
point of leaving by baat a number of times but always there has been the
Clipper,
like prosperity under Hoover - just around the corner.
Now I
am mailing this on
the Japan and probably if I had any sense would get
on the Japan too.
The days have
dragged along interminably and I am
awfully
lonesome. In the
second place
I am sunk over the loss of the
old Hongkong Clipper with Musick and Sellers.
We have had only brief
and conflicting reports but it does appear as the time wears on that the
crew are
all dead and the ship a total
her
Poor gene Sellers! I sent
a telegram expressing sympathy and am writing her by this same mail.
Isn't it terrible to think of
price
those men all lost - it seems such a terrible
to pay.
Bond came down today from Hankow and he is here now with
me .
The
cerned.
situation at Hankow is very much improved so far as CNAC is con-
The M.D.
is definitely through and P.Y. Wong has been selected as
nis successor•
Revenue is much better and the future looks as bright as
any future can look just now in China.
I am writing this letter on my "Christmas present"
incidentally I like very much.
which
brief case. I'm crazy about it.
It weighs only 8f Ibs"and fits into my
Got a wire from Van Zandt that Alameda confirmed
for the gilrs on Jan. 29th and assume that you are
sending their trunks
along to Honolulu ahead of time.
Sorry that I could not attend to the
details in
connection therewith on account of my extended stay in Hong-
kong.
Isn't it maddening this long delay.
Each time I have been ready
to leave here by boat there has been a Clipper just about ready,
even as
now,
to come on over here.
I assumed that you have kept track through the
newspaper of the schedules and have therefore not telegraphed my plans.
Al so
- have not written for each sailing it seemed, including this one,,
that I would arrive before
the boat.
I did write to you once when I
thought you would
certainly get my letter before I would make a personal
appearance.
And I have had no word of any kind from you.
I am just
wondering if that dumb bell Van Zandt is responsible for not forwarding
your letters by ordinary means instead of waiting for the Clipper.
I now expect to leave here on Sunday and arrive that day at
the Manila Hotel from where I will immediately call you on the phone.
do hope
that you and the kids are all well.
Hate to think of the girls
going home
so soon after my arrival as I will hardly have a chance to
see them before they will be leaving.
My mail from NY of course gas been
delayed and I do not know what reaction Mr. Trippe had to my suggestion
that I return but am fairly sure that we can get away whenever we want
to •
The Mania market has been improving Eight along and we
will have plenty of money for the girls or any other expense (within
reason)
than
which may come along.
My salary check for January will be more
2000 Pesos and we can draw a like amount from Swan Culbertson and
Fritz if needed.
Also of course we can always draw on the company for
a reasonable amount as advance of travel
expenses.
So dont worry about
finances!
Have been to a few movies, read a great deal and worked on
my book a little.
Othereise
- no hits
no. runs
nor errors!
All my love
your own
Bik
